posts.cooked: How did teams achieve duel intakes? Was the additional complexity worth it?

posts.name: Hayden Show
posts.cooked: We did, it was very nice for doing clean-up by the speaker or midfield. It wasnt too complex, just mirroring our intake with a couple added belts so it all ran off 1 motor plus a central roller on its own motor. I think enginerds also had a similarish design, but you can check it out in their BTB . Also, 3534 had a 4 side intake which was pretty cool.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
While we looked at doing true dual intakes (we technically can intake both from the floor and directly from the source through our shooter), the weight and space penalty didn‚Äôt make sense for us.

When we looked at the game, the main motivation for having a dual intake would have been so you could intake and shoot from the same side of the robot (our intake passes notes to the shooter on the other side of the robot) to help with speeding up certain autos or reducing time for shooting missed/fed shots close to the speaker. Since we didn‚Äôt have weight for it though, we realized our shooter was technically capable of flipping over to shoot out the intake-side of the robot, so we added that functionality for certain close-range shots (though it wasn‚Äôt really used), which basically accomplished the same thing as having two intakes as far as we were concerned.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: If you haven‚Äôt already, you should definitely check out 125, 3005, 1706,  and 118 for some good examples.

we did 4 side, and honestly it was cool but nearly useless in a lot of situations. The cool bit was that we really didnt have to worry about orientation going in‚Ä¶ other than the fact that 1 intake was substantially quicker than the others.

Screenshot 2024-04-29 121856 1712√ó903 112 KB Screenshot 2024-04-29 121913 1405√ó941 84.9 KB Our front/back intake. helped a lot for cleanup. we ran one set of rollers on each side from one motor to avoid using gears. was not very complex but we definitely used the side opposite of the shooter more so im not sure if it was neccesary.

I think you mean ‚Äúdual‚Äù

but yes, I‚Äôm a fan of multiple intakes. We‚Äôve never made a two-intake robot because it‚Äôs hard to sell to the team.   I‚Äôve also advocated for a triangle three-wheeled swerve with an intake on every side.

I got a first-person explanation for 118‚Äôs at worlds.  it is amazing, but risky because they run it all the time‚Ä¶can pick up accidentally, then you have two notes.    I also heard one team had four intakes. image 916√ó547 44.9 KB

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
We actually run both of the intake rollers backwards once the robot has detected it has a note chambered and ready to shoot. This helps prevent picking up a second note unintentionally.

However the driver has a separate intake button that allows us to pick up a second note for a Momentary amount of time. Once one of the beam break sensors on either intake detects a second note passing through it it stops all the intake rollers and the lights on the robot turn pink. After 1 second half of the lights turn off and the other half turn off after 2 seconds and the robot automatically ejects the second note. This was to make it clear to the refs that we are carrying two notes but that automation is preventing the robot from having ‚ÄúGreater than Momentary‚Äù control off a second note to keep from violating G409.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: We had front and back intakes. It was simple with only one diverter axle needing to be powered in either direction and a small deflection plate. During one rebuild the motor was nearly  removed because I don‚Äôt think the driver ever picked up from the back. Another couple of ounces on the robot weight and it would have been gone.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.custom_user_title: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.cooked:
7407 implemented dual intakes (front and back). We designed our indexer from the start to intake notes from both sides, but did not fully implement this design until our week 4 event. You can find more details on our build blog including the CAD.

The added complexity was mostly needed in the prototyping stage, although we did have to do some testing with different rollers/wheels once we built the robot in order to get it working at a level we liked.

image 562√ó750 85.5 KB

image 562√ó750 85.5 KB

image 562√ó750 85.5 KB

As for wether it was worth it or not, pre-worlds I would have been skeptical. We used it a couple times in competition when our primary intake took big hits and died, and once our twice while cleaning up in our wing. Where the two intakes really shined was at worlds. While we were getting fed, we were able to use the dual intakes to commonly pick up notes in front the amp or against the alliance wall. This was totally worth it, because we could clean up faster. A couple videos below of us using it in comp:

Qual 38

Qual 94

Elims Match 10

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Ours is still a w.i.p. we designed an over the bumper intake, but did not end up making/installing it due to time constraints.

BarStockBumperIntake - COPY v6 1520√ó850 409 KB

BarStockBumperIntake - COPY v6 1520√ó850 409 KB

BarStockBumperIntake - COPY v6 1520√ó850 409 KB

We plan to finish it during the off-season now before events we signed up for. However it installs overtop of our under the bumper intake/static shooter which we used and loved this season. This way we have dual intakes with two different purposes. The under is best for shooting into the speaker and picking up pieces in the middle of the field and if there is active  defense that could damage the over. Then over is best for dumping into the amp and picking up pieces at the walls.

Why do we want to do both? The Challenge

I would suggest looking at what 1690 did with the side wheels to help herd the pieces towards the middle. Our drivers learned how to center them and with lots of practice (at the events) got the process down.
